title: Documentary journalist calls Meghan & Harry 'bruised and vulnerable'
text:
Meghan Markle and Prince Harry appeared “bruised and vulnerable” during the filming of the ITV documentary chronicling their Africa tour.

This is according to Tom Bradby, the journalist who spoke to the royal couple as part of the one-hour ‘Harry & Meghan: An African Journey’ documentary, which aired last Sunday on ITV.

Speaking to US news show ‘Good Morning America’ yesterday, Bradby – who currently presents the News at Ten – said he went into the project simply hoping to chronicle their tour of Africa, but soon realised “everything wasn’t entirely rosy behind the scenes”.

READ MORE: Meghan Markle all smiles for first appearance since admitting to 'struggle'

The emotional documentary, filmed over the 10 days of the Sussexes’ royal tour, saw the Duke and Duchess, 35 and 38 respectively, confess to the “struggle” they have faced in recent months.

“The reality I found was just a couple that seemed a bit bruised and vulnerable,” he told the US programme, ahead of the documentary itself airing last night in the US at 10pm ET. “With mental health you have to be careful which words you use, but that’s what I found.”

Of his relationship with the couple, he said: “I’d seen them obviously before we left and had a pretty long chat and so I formed a certain view there. And I speak to Harry relatively often and have done over the years so, as I said, I knew that things weren’t entirely brilliant behind the scenes, but it sort of built as the tour went on really.”

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle pictured on October 2, the last day of their South Africa tour. [Photo: Getty] More

Meghan Markle attends the One Young World Summit opening ceremony at the Royal Albert Hall on 22 October 2019. [Photo: Getty] More

“It seemed the right journalistic thing to do to try and tell that story as empathetically as I could, that seemed like the approach to take on this occasion,” he added, justifying his approach.

A number of revelations came out during the documentary itself, including the Duchess’ confession her friends “warned [her] off Harry” and the Duke addressing his alleged rift with brother Prince William: “As brothers you have good days and bad days.”

READ MORE: Meghan Markle: 'Not many people have asked if I'm OK - it's a struggle'

Yesterday, Duchess Meghan made her first public appearance since the documentary’s release, attending the One Young World Summit Opening Ceremony Ceremony at the Royal Albert Hall in London, without her husband.

The Sussexes will soon be taking some time from the public in upcoming months, a royal source confirmed to CNN.

The family will take “family time” off from around mid-November onwards, it is believed, and will divide their time between the US and the UK.
description: Speaking on 'Good Morning America', the journalist and presenter opened up about his behind-the-scenes insight into the royal couple.
